content: BO ZHU@GT Bo Zhu Assistant Professor, School of Interactive Computing Georgia Institute of Technology Office: Klaus 3146, GT Campus, Atlanta Email: bo.zhu@gatech.edu About Me I am an Associate Professor in the School of Interactive Computing at Georgia Tech. My research interests lie in computer graphics, computational physics, and scientific machine learning. My primary focus is to develop geometric data structures and numerical algorithms for solving computational challenges associated with various kinds of physical systems. I am consistently fascinated by the beauty and complexity of fluids, with a particular emphasis on simulating their interfacial dynamics, vortical structures, and topological evolution. For these works, I was awarded the NSF Career Award in 2022. Prior to relocating to Atlanta, I spent five wonderful years as an Assistant Professor of Computer Science at Dartmouth College. I formerly worked as a postdoc researcher at MIT CSAIL. I earned my Ph.D. from the Computer Science Department at Stanford University, under the guidance of Prof. Ron Fedkiw. My B.Eng. and M.Sc. degrees were obtained at Shanghai Jiao Tong University. [SCA 2025] This year, I am co-organizing the 24th Symposium on Computer Animation (SCA 2025) together with Prof. Yin Yang from the University of Utah. SCA 2025 will be co-located with ACM SIGGRAPH in downtown Vancouver from August 8 to 10. We would sincerely appreciate it if you would consider submitting your work and/or sponsoring this long-standing symposium in computer animation! [NSF IRES: Summer Research Intern Opportunity] Starting in the fall of 2022, I began leading a three-year research project on Physical AI Design, sponsored by the NSF Office of International Science and Engineering. We are actively seeking summer research interns in the areas of physics simulation, machine learning, and user interface design. If you are interested in collaborating with us, please don't hesitate to submit your application. Additional information about the internship can be found on the project webpage.
